title: 106_hr2661
content: The Act titled "American Indian Education Foundation Act of 1999" amends Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code, by adding a new chapter 216 for the American Indian Education Foundation. The American Indian Education Foundation is a federally chartered charitable and nonprofit corporation with perpetual existence, incorporated in the District of Columbia. The American Indian Education Foundation, a federally chartered nonprofit corporation, defines terms related to American Indian education and Bureau funded schools. Its purposes include encouraging private gifts for the benefit of the Office of Indian Education Programs and supporting educational opportunities for American Indian students. The American Indian Education Foundation, a federally chartered nonprofit corporation, aims to support educational opportunities for American Indian students attending Bureau funded schools. The foundation's governing body, the board of directors, exercises powers and consists of at least 11 members as outlined in its constitution and bylaws. The board of the American Indian Education Foundation consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs as nonvoting members. Board members must be U.S. citizens with knowledge or experience in American Indian education, representing diverse viewpoints. The foundation's officers include a secretary elected from the board members. The American Indian Education Foundation board consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs as nonvoting members. The officers, as outlined in the constitution and bylaws, include a secretary who serves as the chief operating officer knowledgeable in education matters. Board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The foundation has the power to adopt and amend its constitution and bylaws for property management and affairs regulation. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to amend its constitution and bylaws, adopt a corporate seal, make contracts, acquire and transfer property, sue and be sued, and perform acts necessary for its purposes. The foundation's principal office is in Washington, D.C., but activities can be conducted throughout the U.S. The foundation must comply with laws on service of process. The American Indian Education Foundation must comply with state laws on service of process. The foundation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority. The Secretary of the Interior appoints initial voting members of the board of directors for the American Indian Education Foundation within 6 months of enactment. Successive boards must conform to the foundation's constitution and bylaws. During the 5-year period after enactment, the Secretary of the Interior can provide support to the American Indian Education Foundation, including personnel, facilities, and funds for board member travel expenses. The foundation must reimburse for services and funds provided. The Secretary of the Interior may continue to provide facilities and support services to the foundation on a reimbursable cost basis after the initial 5-year period.
